RAPID; GOALI: Sources of 1,4-Dioxane in the Cape Fear River Watershed of North Carolina and Treatment Options for 1,4-Dioxane Control

In the past, 1,4-dioxane was widely used as a solvent stabilizer, and it is commonly thought of as a groundwater contaminant that co-occurs with chlorinated solvents. While 1,4-dioxane usage in the context of solvent stabilization has been phased out, 1,4-dioxane continues to be used as an industrial solvent (e.g. textile industry, paper industry, production of brominated flame retardants), and it is a by-product of manufacturing processes involving ethylene oxide (e.g. production of surfactants used in laundry detergents and shampoos, production of certain plastics). In a recent EPA study, data for North Carolina showed that all 1,4-dioxane detections occurred in drinking water derived from surface water. In fact, the four highest 1,4-dioxane concentrations shown for NC systems also represent the four highest reported values nationally. The highest 1,4-dioxane concentration was reported in drinking water sampled in Moore County at the East Moore Water District (EMWD) Intertie (9.2 ìg/L). Water at the EMWD intertie represents water purchased from Harnett County Regional Water Treatment Plant (Lillington, NC), which treats Cape Fear River water. Furthermore, data collected in our laboratory show that 1,4-dioxane is present at concentrations of up to about 90 ìg/L in the Haw River, and in drinking water derived from the Haw River at concentrations of up to 80 ìg/L (Pittsboro, NC). 

The objectives of the proposed research are to (1) identify 1,4-dioxane sources, (2) establish the spatial and temporal variability in 1,4-dioxane concentrations and mass flows, (3) assess 1,4-dioxane removal by existing point-of-use (POU) treatment devices and identify adsorbent properties that govern 1,4-dioxane removal, and (4) develop fundamental process parameters that describe the oxidative transformation of 1,4-dioxane by O3/H2O2, UV/H2O2, and UV/chlorine advanced oxidation processes in a surface water treatment context. To accomplish the proposed results, stream samples and daily composited samples from drinking water providers will be collected and analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). In conjunction with USGS daily stream flow data, the resulting 1,4-dioxane concentration and mass flow results will be used to identify 1,4-dioxane sources, estimate the quantity of 1,4-dioxane released into the environment, and estimate human exposure to 1,4-dioxane via drinking water consumption.

por.por_cntn:
1,4-Dioxane (not to be confused with dioxin) is a likely human carcinogen that is frequently detected in US drinking water. Traditionally, 1,4-dioxane is linked to groundwater contamination because it was a common stabilizer for solvents stored in underground storage tanks. Recent data of the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) show that 1,4-dioxane is also a common surface water contaminant. Wastewater from industries that use 1,4-dioxane as a solvent or generate 1,4-dioxane as a byproduct is a possible source of 1,4-dioxane contamination of surface water. In addition, 1,4-dioxane can be present in consumer products such as detergents, shampoos, and cosmetics. 

We investigated why 1,4-dioxane concentrations are especially high in the Cape Fear River watershed of North Carolina (NC). Our research was motivated by EPA data showing that six of the twelve highest 1,4-dioxane concentrations measured in US drinking water were measured in communities relying on the Cape Fear River watershed as their source. Our goals included (1) identifying sources of 1,4-dioxane, (2) determining 1,4-dioxane concentrations in river water and finished drinking water, (3) assessing the effectiveness of home filtration devices for 1,4-dioxane removal from tap water, and (4) assessing the effectiveness of advanced oxidation processes involving either ozone (with and without hydrogen peroxide) or ultraviolet (UV) light with hydrogen peroxide for the control of 1,4-dioxane in surface water. 

Our approach included the development of a rapid and sensitive analytical method based on gas chromatography and mass spectrometry to measure 1,4-dioxane in water of widely varying quality - from treated wastewater to finished drinking water. To identify possible sources of 1,4-dioxane, we identified 50 sampling points that covered a large portion of the Cape Fear River watershed. Many of the sampling points bracketed wastewater treatment plant discharges. We collected monthly samples from October 2014 through July 2015. Also, we collected daily samples at the raw and finished water sampling taps of three drinking water treatment plants over a period of 2-3 months. In addition, we evaluated two commercially available pitcher filters, one custom pitcher filter containing a tailored adsorbent, and one refrigerator filter for their ability to remove 1,4-dioxane. Finally, we conducted laboratory-scale experiments to assess whether advanced oxidation processes that are based on either ozone or UV light can be used to control 1,4-dioxane in a surface water treatment context.

Our results showed that treated wastewater from three communities located in the headwater region of the Cape Fear River watershed was the principal source of 1,4-dioxane. Treated wastewater from other communities in the watershed had no measurable impact on 1,4-dioxane concentrations in the receiving streams. Based on the locations of the wastewater discharges, we estimate that more than one million people receive drinking water from sections of the Cape Fear River watershed, where 1,4­ dioxane concentrations are elevated.

1,4-Dioxane concentrations in the drinking water source of one small community frequently exceeded the NC stream water quality standard for 1,4-dioxane (0.35 parts per billion) by a factor of 10 and at times greater than 100. Results also showed that measurable removal of 1,4-dioxane was not obtained by the conventional drinking water treatment processes of this community. Similar to this community, almost all drinking water treatment plants in the affected region lack treatment processes capable of removing 1,4­-dioxane. One treatment plant using ozone was able to oxidatively transform about two-thirds of the 1,4-dioxane in the raw water.

Results from the evaluation of commercially available home filtration devices illustrated that 1,4-dioxane is not effectively removed when treating a volume of water corresponding to the stated manufacturer's expected life. A custom pitcher filter containing a tailored carbonaceous resin showed greater promise for 1,4-dioxane removal and may serve as a basis for the development of more effective home filtration devices for the control of 1,4-dioxane and other organic contaminants that exhibit a high affinity for water.

In the context of drinking water treatment at the municipal scale, our results show that both ozone and UV-based advanced oxidation processes have the potential to effectively control 1,4-dioxane in surface water with moderate levels of dissolved organic matter.

In this study, we collaborated closely with staff from affected drinking water utilities and the NC Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ). DEQ staff are now modifying discharge permits of the wastewater treatment plants that are the principal sources of 1,4-dioxane. We anticipate that public health benefits will result from this research by (1) eliminating sources of 1,4­-dioxane that contribute to the contamination of drinking water sources and (2) by supporting the development of more effective home filtration devices and large-­scale treatment approaches for the control of 1,4­-dioxane.
